mass.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a large amount of a substance which does not have a definite or regular shape
mass.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: The food had congealed into a sticky mass.
mass.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a large amount or quantity of something
mass.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a large amount of something, or a lot of people or things
mass.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Masses of books covered every surface in the room.
mass.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: There was a mass of people around the club entrance.
The road was blocked by a solid mass of protesters.
mass.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the main ceremony in some Christian churches, especially the Roman Catholic Church, which celebrates the last meal that Jesus Christ ate
say/celebrate Mass (=perform this ceremony as a priest)
mass.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: What time do you go to mass?
Will I see you at morning Mass?
mass.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: a piece of music written to be performed at the ceremony of mass
mass.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: the amount of material in something
mass.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: The Sun makes up 99.9% of the mass of our solar system.
mass.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: involving or intended for a very large number of people
mass.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: Email has made mass mailings possible at the touch of a button.
mass.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to come together, or to make people or things come together, in a large group
mass.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: Western reports say that troops have been massing in the region since December.
grey clouds massing behind the mountains
Both countries have massed troops along the border.
